event.name: The Algorithmic Judge: Navigating the Ethics of AI
event.description: As algorithms and AI automate decisions in law, finance, and daily life, what new ethical frontiers must we navigate? This panel confronts the challenges of bias, accountability, and fairness.
event.dynamics: A 'Town Hall' style debate. After brief initial statements from each panelist, the moderator will facilitate questions directly from the audience, fostering a community-wide conversation.

participants.name: Dr. Laura Jenkins
participants.bio: A professor at Georgetown Law specializing in technology law and public policy. She has advised governmental bodies on regulating emerging technologies.

participants.name: Dr. Wei Zhang
participants.bio: A researcher in AI Ethics from Google AI. His work focuses on developing technical solutions for fairness, accountability, and transparency (FAT) in machine learning models.

participants.name: Dr. Tariq Hassan
participants.bio: A sociologist from the London School of Economics who studies the future of work. His research examines the societal impacts of automation on labor displacement and inequality.

participants.name: Dr. Olivia Bisset
participants.bio: A moral philosopher from the Sorbonne University. She writes on applied ethics, focusing on questions of machine consciousness, algorithmic responsibility, and deontological constraints on AI.

roles.name: Moderator
roles.description: Manages the town hall format, ensures a respectful and productive dialogue, and selects questions from the audience.

roles.name: Panelist
roles.description: Offers an expert opinion on the ethics of automation and responds to challenging questions from the community.
